facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 1108 to 1110 of 1964 are appeals by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Civil Appeal Nos. 1108 to 1110 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeals directed against judgment and order dated August 1, 1962 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 20 and 21 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Civil Appeal Nos. 1108 to 1110 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 1, 1962 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 20 and 21 of 1959.

facts.text: Income Tax Reference No. 20 of 1959 made at instance of Ms Fatehchand Murlidhar.

anchor.surface_text: One of the references Income Tax Reference No. 20 of 1959 was made at the instance of M s Fatehchand Murlidhar, and the other Income Tax Reference No. 21 of 1959 was made at the instance of Shri Murlidhar Himatsingka.

facts.text: Question in Ref 20: whether income of Murlidhar Himatsingka for his share in Messrs. Basantlal Ghanshyamdas for 1952-53 and 1953-54 rightly excluded from income of applicant firm.

anchor.surface_text: In the former reference the question referred was whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka for his share in the firm of Messrs. Basantlal Ghanshyamdas for the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54 was rightly excluded from the income of the applicant firm.

facts.text: Income Tax Reference No. 21 of 1959 made at instance of Shri Murlidhar Himatsingka.

anchor.surface_text: One of the references Income Tax Reference No. 20 of 1959 was made at the instance of M s Fatehchand Murlidhar, and the other Income Tax Reference No. 21 of 1959 was made at the instance of Shri Murlidhar Himatsingka.

facts.text: Question in Ref 21: whether income of Murlidhar Himatsingka for his share in Messrs. Basantlal Ghanshyamdas for 1955-56 rightly included in his personal assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In the latter reference the question referred was whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the income of Murlidhar Himatsingha for his share in the firm of Messrs. Basantlal Ghanshyamdas for the assessment year 1955-56 was rightly included in his personal assessment for that year.

facts.text: Murlidhar Himatsingka carried on business in shellac, jute, hessian etc. under name Fatehchand Murlidhar at 14/1 Clive Row and 71 Burtolla Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Murli- dhar Himatsingka was carrying on business in shellac, jute, hessian etc. under the name and style of Fatehchand Murlidhar at 14/ 1, Clive Row and 71, Burtolla Street, Calcutta.

facts.text: Murlidhar Himatsingka was a partner in registered firm Messrs Basantlal Ghanshyamdas with 2/8 share.

anchor.surface_text: He was also a partner in the registered firm, Messrs Basantlal Ghanshyamdas having /2/8 share.

facts.text: On December 21, 1949, deed of partnership executed by Murlidhar Himatsingka and his two sons Madanlal Himatsingka, Radhaballav Himatsingka and grandson Mahabir Prasad Himatsingka.

anchor.surface_text: On December 21, 1949, a deed of partnership was executed by the said Murlidhar Himatsingka and his two sons, Madanlal Himatsingka and Radhaballav Himatsingka and a grandson named Mahabir Prasad Himatsingka.

facts.text: Deed recited Murlidhar Himatsingka too old and infirm to look after businesses, sons already managing.

anchor.surface_text: The deed recited that Murlidhar Himatsingka had become too old and infirm to look after the various businesses and that Madanlal and Radha Ballav were already practically managing the business

facts.text: Sons and grandson agreed to contribute capital: Rs.10,000, Rs.5,000, Rs.5,000 respectively to Fatehchand Murlidhar.

anchor.surface_text: and that they had signified their intention to become the partners of the said firm Fatehchand Murlidhar and had agreed to companytribute capital, Rupees ten thousand, Rupees five thousand and Rupees five thousand respectively.

facts.text: Clause 5 of deed: Profits and losses for share of Murlidhar in Basantlal Ghanshyamdas belong to present partnership, divided per shares, but capital exclusive to Murlidhar.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 of this deed is important for our purpose and reads as follows- The profits and losses for the share of the said Murlidhar Himatsingka as partner in the said partnership firm of Basantlal Ghanshyamdas shall belong to the present partnership and shall be divided and borne by the parties hereto in accordance with the shares as specified hereafter, but the capital with its assets and liabilities will belong exclusively to Murlidhar Himatsingka

facts.text: Shares in new partnership: Murlidhar 6 annas, Madanlal 4 annas, Radhaballav 3 annas, Mahabirprasad 3 annas.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 provides- The Profits and losses  if any  of the partnership including the shares of the profits and losses of the said partnership firm of Basantlal Ghanshyamdas aforesaid shall be divided and borne by and between the parties in the following manner-- Party hereto of the First Part-Six annas  Murlidhar Himatsingka . Party hereto of the Second Part-Four annas  Madanlal Himatsingka . Party hereto of the Third Part-Three annas  Radhaballav Himatsingka . Party hereto of the Fourth Part-Three annas  Mahabirprasad Himatsingka .

facts.text: For assessment year 1955-56, Income Tax Officer included income from share in Basantlal Ghanshyamdas in individual assessment of Murlidhar Himatsingka.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1955-56 the Income Tax Officer included the income-from the share in the registered firm of Basantlal Ghanshyamdas in the individual assessment of Murlidhar Himatsingka,

facts.text: Murlidhar Himatsingka appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar Himatsingka appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held under s.23(5)(a) share assessed in hands of Murlidhar as partner; agreement subsequent disposition after profits earned.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to s. 23 5  a  of the Act. he held that as Murlidhar Himatsingka was a partner in the registered firm of Basantlal Ghanshyamdas, his share had to be assessed in his hands. He further held that the agreement was merely an arrangement which came into force after the profits were earned and number before they were earned. He held that this agreement being a subsequent disposition of profits, after they had been earned, had to be disregarded.

facts.text: Murlidhar appealed to Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, which dismissed appeal agreeing with AAC.

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar Himatsingka appealed to the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal. The Appellate Tribunal heard this appeal together with the two appeals filed by M s Fatehchand Murlidhar. The Appellate Tribunal, agreeing with the views of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held it was diversion of income by Murlidhar after accrual, not at source; answered questions in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that it was a case of diversion of in- companye by Murlidhar Himatsingka after it had accrued to him and it was number a diversion at the source by any overriding interest. In the result, the High Court answered the questions in the affirmative in both the references.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave; appeals before it.

anchor.surface_text: Murlidhar Himatsingka and M s Fatehchand Murlidhar having obtained special leave, the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court held agreement dated Dec 21, 1949 constituted sub-partnership in respect of Murlidhar's share in Basantlal Ghanshyamdas.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the agreement dated December 21, 1949, companystituted a sub-partnership in respect of Murlidhars share in M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas.

facts.text: High Court answered questions in affirmative in both references.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court answered the questions in the affirmative in both the references.

facts.text: References made by Income Tax Appellate Tribunal under s.66(1) of 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Calcutta in two cases referred to it by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act  XI of 1922  hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: Clause 13 of deed: Murlidhar has sole control and direction of partnership business.

anchor.surface_text: In clause 13 it is provided that the party hereto of the First Part shall have the sole companytrol and direction of the partnership business and his opinion shall prevail if there be any dispute between the parties hereto.

facts.text: Income Tax Appellate Tribunal heard appeal together with two appeals by Fatehchand Murlidhar.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal heard this appeal together with the two appeals filed by M s Fatehchand Murlidhar.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds income diverted before reaching Murlidhar due to sub-partnership.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion we hold that the High Court was in error in holding that there was numberquestion of an overriding ogligation in this case and that the income remained the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka in spite of the sub- partnership created by him under the agreement dated December 21, 1949.

issues.text: whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka for his share in the firm of Messrs. Basantlal Ghanshyamdas for the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54 was rightly excluded from the income of the applicant firm

issues.text: whether the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka, from the firm of M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas, in which he was a partner, should be included in his personal assessment or in the assessment of the firm of Fatehchand Murlidhar, to which Murlidhar Himatsingka had purported to assign the profits and losses from M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas

anchor.surface_text: the real question raised by these references is whether the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka, from the firm of M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas, in which he was a partner, should be included in his personal assessment or in the assessment of the firm of Fatehchand Murlidhar, to which Murlidhar Himatsingka had purported to assign the profits and losses from M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas.

issues.answer: in the assessment of the firm of Fatehchand Murlidhar

issues.text: whether the agreement dated December 21, 1949, has succeeded in diverting the income from Murlidhar's share in M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas to M s Fatehchand Murlidhar before it reached Murlidhar

anchor.surface_text: The first point that arises is whether the agreement dated December 21, 1949, has succeeded in diverting the income from Murlidhus share in M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas to M s Fatehchand Murlidhar before it reached Murlidhar.

issues.text: whether the Indian Income Tax Act contemplates the application of s. 23(5)(a) twice, such that the income received from the registered firm Basantlal Ghanshyamdas by Murlidhar cannot be carried to the assessment of another registered firm Fatehchand Murlidhar

arguments.claim: Partner's share in a firm is property capable of being assigned, and upon assignment, the vendor partner holds it as trustee for the purchaser, so the income received belongs to the purchaser, not the partner.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellants, Mr. A. K. Sen, contends that a partners share is property capable of being assigned, mortgaged, charged and dealt with as any other property, and where a partner sells his share to a stranger, though that stranger does number become a partner yet the vendor partner holds the property as trustee for the purchaser and consequently the income received by the partner is number his income but the income of the purchaser.

holdings.text: the agreement dated December 21, 1949, constituted a sub-partnership in respect of Murlidhar's share in M/s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the agreement dated December 21, 1949, companystituted a sub-partnership in respect of Murlidhars share in M s Basantlal Ghanshyamdas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 5 provides profits and losses from share belong to present partnership divided per shares; capital exclusive to Murlidhar but P/L shared indicates sub-partnership not mere assignment

holdings.text: High Court was in error in holding that there was no question of an overriding obligation in this case and that the income remained the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka in spite of the sub-partnership created by him under the agreement dated December 21, 1949

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion we hold that the High Court was in error in holding that there was numberquestion of an overriding ogligation in this case and that the income remained the income of Murlidhar Himatsingka in spite of the sub- partnership created by him under the agreement dated December 21, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-partnership creates superior title diverting income at source before accrual to partner; partner receives on behalf of sub-partners per diversion test in CIT v Sitaldas Tirathdas

holdings.text: the case of Ratilal B. Daftari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay was rightly decided

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the case of Ratilal B. Daftari v. Commis- sioner of Income-tax, Bombay 1  was rightly decided, although the reasoning given by the learned Judges of the High Court has to some extent number been accepted by Hidayatullah, J.,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Similar facts of agreement sharing P/L of partner's capital contribution in main firm constituted sub-partnership diverting income

holdings.text: the Calcutta High Court decision relied on by the High Court and the learned counsel for the respondent Mahaliram Santhalia v. Commissioner of Income-tax was wrongly decided
holdings.reasoning_summary: Failed to recognize sub-partnership creates overriding title diverting income before it becomes partner's income; treated as mere voluntary disposition

holdings.text: there is no substance in this contention [that the Indian Income Tax Act does not contemplate the application of s. 23(5)(a) twice]
holdings.reasoning_summary: No warrant in Act; benamidar can be partner per precedent but income assessable to beneficial owner; s.23(5)(a) apportions among partners not prevents sub-assessment

holdings.text: a benamidar can be a partner in a firm
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming precedent: benamidar nominal partner without beneficial interest; real owner assessable on income received by benamidar

holdings.text: The object of s. 23(5)(a) is not to assess the firm itself but to apportion the income among the various partners
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory purpose supports assessing true owners via sub-partnership or HUF/karta precedents

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay v Sitaldas Tirathdas
precedents.cited_proposition: true test is whether the amount sought to be deducted never reached the assessee as his income; difference between diversion by overriding obligation before reaching assessee and application after receipt
precedents.cited_holding: Where by the obligation income is diverted before it reaches the assessee, it is deductible but where the income is required to be applied to discharge an obligation after such income reaches the assessee, the same consequence, in law, does not follow.

precedents.cited_proposition: memorandum dividing income from managing agency commission; income no longer joint family income despite karta remaining partner
precedents.cited_holding: the document effectively divided the income and the income could no longer be treated as that of the Hindu undivided family

precedents.case_name: K A Ramachar v Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: partner alone entitled to profits; assignment does not give stranger direct claim
precedents.cited_holding: By the deeds in question, the assessee merely allowed a payment to his wife and daughters to constitute a valid discharge in favour of the firm but what was paid was, in law, a portion of his profits

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. Abdul Rahim 1 55 I.T.R 651

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax, Gujarat v. Abdul Rahim 1 55 I.T.R 651 that registration of the firm could not be refused on the ground that a partner was a benamidar

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Gujarat v Abdul Rahim
precedents.cited_proposition: benamidar partner is trustee; no beneficial interest but can be assessed as per real owner for tax
precedents.cited_holding: a benamidar is a mere trustee of the real owner and he has no beneficial interest in the profits of the business of the real owner
